bug.short_desc: Switch to inform to reduce background traffic while on mobile connections

long_desc.thetext: When I connect through my cell phone, either WiFi hotspot or USB connection, NM does not have a clue that the other side is a cell phone. But if we could have a switch that toggles this "mobile mode" (or something like that), it would be great. Then yum, dnf and others could respect that to not do package updates and alikes while on a mobile connection.

Since version 1.2 each device has a 'metered' property which is inherited from the connection active on the device. The default value for connection.metered is 'guess' which means that we use some heuristics to determine the actual value. First, any GSM/CDMA connection will be automatically considered metered; then we use the DHCP options announced by Android phones to determine if the connection is a Ethernet-USB or WiFi tethered one. It is also possible for users to manually set the metered status of a given connection.
In addition to the per-device metered setting (available in the
nmcli -f general.device,general.metered device show
output) there also a global property, only exported through D-Bus (org.fd.NM.Metered) representing the metered status of the device with the default route. Applications can query this attribute to know whether they should limit data usage.
